head.title: In Bosnia War, Blame Enough for Everyone

hedline.hl1: In Bosnia War, Blame Enough for Everyone

block.p: As a freelance journalist who spent last winter traveling across Bosnia and Herzegovina with a relief convoy, I well appreciate "In Bosnia, the War That Can't Be Seen" (The Week in Review, Dec. 25), discussing difficulties of access and the dangers facing reporters there.

As a freelance journalist who spent last winter traveling across Bosnia and Herzegovina with a relief convoy, I well appreciate "In Bosnia, the War That Can't Be Seen" (The Week in Review, Dec. 25), discussing difficulties of access and the dangers facing reporters there.

Back home, I set down my experiences in an article that contained my eyewitness accounts of the aftermath of a Muslim "ethnic cleansing" campaign directed against the Croat inhabitants of the Travnik region, systematic profiteering from internationally donated humanitarian aid by Muslim army commanders in the city of Zenica, incidents of homicidal fury against Muslims in the Croat town of Tomislavgrad and similar activities by Serbs in the valley of the Urbas river.
No publication in the United States has wanted to publish my account. Surely, truth is ill served when what is seen cannot be told.

One must conclude that the commitment of the news media to demonizing the Serbs, along with a general ignorance of the political and cultural history of the South Slavs, have been more prejudicial to balanced perceptions of the conflict than any events on the ground.

We have fallen far from the heady days when W. J. Stillman braved the Balkan snows on horseback to provide the readers of The Times of London with accurate, insightful and deeply informed dispatches describing the Herzegovina insurrection of 1875. VANNI CAPPELLI Bronxville, N.Y., Dec. 26, 1994
